Title:
A Cluster of Olfactory Receptor Genes Linked to Frugivory in
Bats
Abstract:
Diversity of the mammalian olfactory receptor (OR)
repertoire has been globally reshaped by niche specialisation across
Eutheria. However, little is known about the variability of the OR
repertoire at a shallower evolutionary timeframe. The vast monophyletic
bat radiation exhibits an extraordinary variety of trophic and sensory
specialisations. Unlike other mammals, bats possess a unique and
diversified OR gene repertoire. Focusing on recently diverged lineages,
we investigated whether the evolution of the OR gene repertoire has been
influenced by ecological niche specialisations, such as
sensory-modalities, diet and other life history traits. The OR gene
repertoires of 27 bat species spanning the whole chiropteran radiation
were amplified and sequenced. For each species, intact and
non-functional genes were assessed, and the OR gene abundances in each
gene family were compared. We identified a unique OR pattern tied to the
frugivorous diet of New World fruit-eating bats and a similar convergent
pattern in the Old World fruit-eating bats. Our results show a strong
association between niche specialisation and OR repertoire diversity
even at a shallow evolutionary timeframe.
